title: Man with severe toothache killed himself after 'he had enough of the pain'
text:

A man living in agony as he waited to get his wisdom tooth removed on the NHS killed himself after telling his mum "he'd had enough of the pain".

An inquest heard Anthony Hoskins, from Southampton, had been on the waiting list but his mum Shirley was saving up to pay for private treatment after seeing the pain her son was in.

A statement from Mrs Hoskins said he began to suffer from tooth ache in January and after seeing a dentist the pain got worse.

The 38-year-old employment agency worker started taking "large amounts" of mixed paracetamol and ibuprofen painkillers to cope with the pain so his mum began saving to pay £1,500 to have them removed privately.

(Image: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Mr Hoskins was prescribed stronger painkillers and drank a glass of whiskey a night to help him sleep and in March he told his mum "he'd had enough of the pain" but she told him she had saved £900 at this point and it would only be a few weeks.

"Anthony was just a normal man who got on with life," she said.

"He enjoyed playing computer games and had no financial problems. His rent was always paid, along with other utilities, and he would see me weekly."

She added: "Anthony is at rest now and will not suffer anymore pain.

"The really sad thing is that it cost me almost the same amount of money to pay for his death that it would have to have private dental treatment."

Mr Hoskin was found dead in his flat April 3 by police who had broken in after his mum raised concerns about his welfare.

PC Simon Collins told the hearing at Winchester Coroner's Court police had been called by Mrs Hoskins who said she had not heard from him for a couple of days and he had gone home from work with an illness the previous week.

A bank receipt found in the address showed Mr Hoskins was overdrawn by £3,000.

The inquest heard he was often asking for overtime at work in the weeks prior to his death.

A statement from Dr Gabriella Day, of Burgess Road Surgery, said Mr Hoskins had last visited the practice in August 2018 with a tooth ache complaint.

A post mortem examination was carried out by pahologist Dr Eleanor Jaynes, who provided a cause of death as hanging.

Acting area coroner Samantha Marsh recorded a conclusion of suicide.
